title: Setting Arbitrary Cookie at kitcrm.com

profile.name: Shopify
profile.about: Shopify is a multi-channel commerce platform that helps people sell online, in-store, and everywhere in between.

vulnerability_information:
Hey

The `src` parameter of Image is not being sanitized which allows me to set cookies at `kitcrm.com`

#### Proof of Concept

1. Create a post at `https://kitcrm.com/pages/ID/manual_posts/new`
2. Select ` Schedule for Later `
3. Go to Scheduled Posts `https://kitcrm.com/pages/ID/manual_posts`
4. Click `Edit` on your post
5. Select any random photo and click "Update"
6. Intercept the request, Change the `manual_post[image_url]` to 
`data:image/svg+xml,<svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><circle r='100'></circle><foreignObject><html xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml'><meta http-equiv='Set-Cookie' content='ppp=qqq' /></html></foreignObject></svg>`
7. Check `document.cookie` from the console

```
POST /pages/176625/manual_posts/30923 HTTP/1.1
Host: kitcrm.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.11; rv:51.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/51.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Referer: https://kitcrm.com/pages/176625/manual_posts/30923/edit
Cookie: 
Connection: close
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------153019791019196005451079530934
Content-Length: 3600
```

vulnerability_information_html:
Hey

The src parameter of Image is not being sanitized which allows me to set cookies at kitcrm.com

Proof of Concept

  1. Create a post at https://kitcrm.com/pages/ID/manual_posts/new
  2. Select Schedule for Later
  3. Go to Scheduled Posts https://kitcrm.com/pages/ID/manual_posts
  4. Click Edit on your post
  5. Select any random photo and click "Update"
  6. Intercept the request, Change the manual_post[image_url] to data:image/svg+xml,<svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><circle r='100'></circle><foreignObject><html xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml'><meta http-equiv='Set-Cookie' content='ppp=qqq' /></html></foreignObject></svg>
  7. Check document.cookie from the console

activities.message:
Thank you for reporting this bug! This is an automated response to let you know that we've received your issue, and we'll process it as soon as possible.

Our team is busy triaging and fixing HackerOne reports, and it may take us up to 1 week (or more) to triage any given issue. Don't worry, we'll get to yours!

While you are waiting, you can read over our list of non applicable issues listed on our program page: https://hackerone.com/shopify. Make sure your issue isn't listed!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for reporting this bug! This is an automated response to let you know that we've received your issue, and we'll process it as soon as possible.

Our team is busy triaging and fixing HackerOne reports, and it may take us up to 1 week (or more) to triage any given issue. Don't worry, we'll get to yours!

While you are waiting, you can read over our list of non applicable issues listed on our program page: https://hackerone.com/shopify. Make sure your issue isn't listed!

activities.message: Thank you for your report. Our engineering team is investigating the issue.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for your report. Our engineering team is investigating the issue.

activities.message: There is no update yet. Please don't expect an update for at least a few more weeks due to the large number of issues we receive. We will give you updates as soon as we have some. If you don't see a message from us, then we don't have any update for you.
activities.markdown_message: There is no update yet. Please don't expect an update for at least a few more weeks due to the large number of issues we receive. We will give you updates as soon as we have some. If you don't see a message from us, then we don't have any update for you.

activities.message: @juanbroullon It's been two months now, Anything here ?
activities.markdown_message: @juanbroullon It's been two months now, Anything here ?

activities.message: >  If you don't see a message from us, then we don't have any update for you.
activities.markdown_message: If you don't see a message from us, then we don't have any update for you.

activities.message:
Thanks again for your report. The affected feature has been deprecated and removed. We have also fixed this issue in other places of Kit where it was present.

We don't believe the ability to set a cookie on kitcrm.com would have any security implications for the application. Since this issue doesn't fall under any of our eligible vulnerability types, this report will not be eligible for a bounty.

Thank you for your interest in improving the security of Shopify!
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks again for your report. The affected feature has been deprecated and removed. We have also fixed this issue in other places of Kit where it was present.

We don't believe the ability to set a cookie on kitcrm.com would have any security implications for the application. Since this issue doesn't fall under any of our eligible vulnerability types, this report will not be eligible for a bounty.

Thank you for your interest in improving the security of Shopify!

activities.message:
@juanbroullon @shopify-peteryaworski 
Hey I was wondering since Open redirect is in scope

This could have been POC for open redirect
```
data:image/svg+xml,<svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><circle r='100'></circle><foreignObject><html xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml'><meta HTTP-EQUIV="Refresh" CONTENT="0; URL=http://www.google.com/" /></html></foreignObject></svg>
```

activities.message:
Hi @dhaval,
Open redirects aren't actually in scope unless they can be used to to demonstrate an additional security impact. This is referenced on the program policy:

> ###Known issues or previously reported vulnerabilities
>
> The following vulnerability types have already been reported and triaged, and won't be fixed. Please do not report any of the following issues. In most cases these issues will be closed as Not Applicable.
> - Open redirects (except in cases where additional security impact can be demonstrated, e.g. stealing authentication tokens or XSS)
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @dhaval,
Open redirects aren't actually in scope unless they can be used to to demonstrate an additional security impact. This is referenced on the program policy:

Known issues or previously reported vulnerabilities

The following vulnerability types have already been reported and triaged, and won't be fixed. Please do not report any of the following issues. In most cases these issues will be closed as Not Applicable.

  • Open redirects (except in cases where additional security impact can be demonstrated, e.g. stealing authentication tokens or XSS)

activities.message:
@shopify-peteryaworski Thank you for more information
Sorry I should have gone through program policy  before asking questions
activities.markdown_message:
@shopify-peteryaworski Thank you for more information
Sorry I should have gone through program policy before asking questions

activities.message:
Hey @dhaval, no apologies necessary. It was a recent change on our scope that made this explicit. We had paid for open redirects in the past but have since changed that because they often have little impact by themselves.

Good luck - I'm looking forward to more reports from you.
Pete
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @dhaval, no apologies necessary. It was a recent change on our scope that made this explicit. We had paid for open redirects in the past but have since changed that because they often have little impact by themselves.

Good luck - I'm looking forward to more reports from you.
Pete

activities.message:
@shopify-peteryaworski 
I thought you treat scope according to the date of submission, Rather than date of fix.

> It was a recent change on our scope that made this explicit.

Well I didn't predict the scope change when I reported the bug
Anyway thanks for the explanation, Have a nice day ahead Peter
activities.markdown_message:
@shopify-peteryaworski
I thought you treat scope according to the date of submission, Rather than date of fix.

It was a recent change on our scope that made this explicit.

Well I didn't predict the scope change when I reported the bug
Anyway thanks for the explanation, Have a nice day ahead Peter

activities.message:
Hi @dhaval,
sorry for not being clear. We do consider inclusion based on submission date. Open redirects have never been in our list of eligible vulnerability types. We used to make exceptions for open redirects, but have not done so in quite some time. The recent addition to the ineligible vulnerability types list was just for additional clarity.

Pete
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @dhaval,
sorry for not being clear. We do consider inclusion based on submission date. Open redirects have never been in our list of eligible vulnerability types. We used to make exceptions for open redirects, but have not done so in quite some time. The recent addition to the ineligible vulnerability types list was just for additional clarity.

Pete
